job_title: Research Assistant in Thunder Bay, ON
pros: Good possibilities for networking. Staff are friendly and close-knit. The researchers are very knowledgeable and helpful. The quality of opportunities for undergraduate research is amazing.
cons: Smaller school/institution, so the name doesn't carry the same weight as bigger institutions and, while the quality of undergraduate research opportunities is high, the quantity might not be. It might be difficult to find exactly what you want, and there is competition.

review_title: A great academic environment for those on the tenure-track
job_title: Professor in Thunder Bay, ON
pros: Since Lakehead is a medium-sized university, one cannot remain anonymous. The workload is reasonable, so that faculty can keep up with student queries and concerns (usually by e-mail rather than through office visits) and it is easy to participate in campus events.
cons: A faculty member does not "own" a course. Contract faculty may acquire seniority, but can be bumped out of an assignment if a tenured faculty require that section to fill out his or her timetable.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Thunder Bay, ON
pros:
- Health Care
- Great professors to work with 
- Reasonable Workload (since you're doing your Master's at the same time) 

VARIES (depends who you are T.Aing for)
- Frequent communication 
- Clear instructions of expectations
cons: Neither professors fault but whoever is in charge of assigning the students to the professors forgot about me. I was without a T.A position and I had to contact and figure out what was going on. Felt forgotten.

job_title: Contract Lecturer in Thunder Bay, ON
pros: Great students, good overall atmosphere, close-knit environment, good colleagues, close to all amenities of living, relatively small class sizes, autonomy.
cons: University is too small to allow contract lecturers and part-time faculty to advance in their careers; management does not communicate with such employees sufficiently.
